instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.A1932: What is A1932? A1932 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook Air from years Late 2018, 2019 with EMC 3184, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-01521..
definitions.820-01521: What is 820-01521? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PPDCIN_G3H: What is PPDCIN_G3H? PPDCIN_G3H Is a power rail that comes directly from the laptop charger..
definitions.PP3V3_G3H_RTC: What is PP3V3_G3H_RTC? PP3V3_G3H_RTC Is one of the first rails that has to come on in order for the USB-C mux chip to be powered in the T2 chip Macbook Pros..
definitions.R7020: What is R7020? Current sense shunt resistor for the charger, the resistors between this and the ISL6259 should be proper rating or else machine will turn off the charger. Measuring pins 27/28 on ISL6259 should give you 20.02 ohms. .
definitions.U7000: What is U7000? U7000 refers to the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging IC on Macbooks from 2008-2012.
definitions.CD3215: What is CD3215? This is a USB-C muxing chip responsible for USB-C communication with devices such as the laptop charger. The most common issue this chip is involved in is when a Macbook wonâ€™t charge or the charger is stuck at 5v instead of going to 20v..

threads.title: MacBook Air <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1932</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>: no power, no fan spin
threads.message:
MacBook Air (Retina, 13-inch, 2019) <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1932</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>
Part Number: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01521</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>

Problem: does not turn ON, no light on LCD, no fan spin
Board: looks pristine, no liquid damage or corrosion

Power on USB PowerMeter with battery disconnected: 
5.12V/7mA when power connected to USB-C port A
5.08V/300mA when power connected to USB-C port B

Voltages:
<SIGNAL>PP20V_USBC_XA_VBUS</SIGNAL>: 5.16V
<SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H</SIGNAL>: 0V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H_RTC</SIGNAL>: 0V
<SIGNAL>CHGR_EN_MVR</SIGNAL>: 0.08V
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>: 0.054V

Fuse: F3000 and F3010 good

Resistance measurements:
F3000 to GND: 28Kohm
F3010 to GND: infinite

threads.title: MacBook Air <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1932</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>: no power, no fan spin
threads.message:
First of all, welcome to the forum!

Looks to have a problem at USB-C ports, as doesn't have same behaviour on both ports.

Post diode mode to ground at <RESISTOR>R7020</RESISTOR>, F7000 and L6960.
BTW, red probe connected at ground!

threads.title: MacBook Air <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1932</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>: no power, no fan spin
threads.message:
Diode measurements to ground (red probe on GND):
<RESISTOR>R7020</RESISTOR>: 0.568
F7000: 1.566
L6960: 0.483

threads.title: MacBook Air <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1932</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>: no power, no fan spin
threads.message:
Do you get voltage at <RESISTOR>R7020</RESISTOR>?
If yes, post some voltages for <CHIP>U7000</CHIP>; <SIGNAL>P_IN</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>AUX_DET</SIGNAL>, VDDA/P.

threads.title: MacBook Air <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1932</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>: no power, no fan spin
threads.message: The voltage on <RESISTOR>R7020</RESISTOR> (<SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H</SIGNAL>) is 0V. All voltages on <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> pins are also 0V.

threads.title: MacBook Air <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1932</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>: no power, no fan spin
threads.message:
The <SIGNAL>PP20V_USBC_XA_VBUS</SIGNAL> is supposed to be 20V the moment the USB-C power is connected to port A. But instead of 20V, there is only 5.16V.
Looking at the schematics, by design, there is no circuit connected on the <SIGNAL>PP20V_USBC_XA_VBUS</SIGNAL> that can change/control the voltage from 20V to 5.16V.
This means that the problem must be on <SIGNAL>PP20V_USBC_XA_VBUS</SIGNAL> (9 decoupling capacitors, <DIODE>D3300</DIODE>, <DIODE>D3301</DIODE>, inside <CHIP>U3100</CHIP> or inside <TRANSISTOR>Q3100</TRANSISTOR>). The problem cannot be after the <TRANSISTOR>Q3100</TRANSISTOR> (N-MOSFET), meaning the problem cannot be on <SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H</SIGNAL> or the circuits on that bus.
Do you think my logic is correct?

threads.title: MacBook Air <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1932</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>: no power, no fan spin
threads.message:
USB-C ports will switch to 20V after <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> appears.
Even more things need to happen also.
Once <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> chip receives VBUS, it should open corresponding Q31/200 MOSFET; <SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H</SIGNAL> must receives 5V from input, as first step.

You probably need to change both <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> chips.
